sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a combustion reaction
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane, CH4(g), in oxygen gas, O2(g), to produce carbon dioxide, CO2(g), and water vapor, H2O(g), given the following balanced chemical equation and standard enthalpies of formation? 

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(g) 

∆H°f( CH4(g) ) = -74.8 kJ/mol
∆H°f( CO2(g) ) = -393.5 kJ/mol
∆H°f( H2O(g) ) = -241.8 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane, we can use the following formula:

∆H°rxn = Σ [∆H°f(products)] - Σ [∆H°f(reactants)]

For the given balanced chemical equation:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(g)

The standard enthalpies of formation are:

∆H°f( CH4(g) ) = -74.8 kJ/mol
∆H°f( CO2(g) ) = -393.5 kJ/mol
∆H°f( H2O(g) ) = -241.8 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

∆H°rxn = [1 × (-393.5 kJ/mol) + 2 × (-241.8 kJ/mol)] - [1 × (-74.8 kJ/mol) + 2 × 0 kJ/mol]

Note that the standard enthalpy of formation for O2(g) is 0 kJ/mol since it is an element in its standard state.

∆H°rxn = (-393.5 - 2 × 241.8 + 74.8) kJ/mol
∆H°rxn = (-393.5 - 483.6 + 74.8) kJ/mol
∆H°rxn = (-802.3) kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane is -802.3 kJ/mol.
